questions.text:
1. Which of the following statements are correct regarding this class of antibody?

* It is most effective in agglutination reactions.

* It has a half-life of 5 days.

* It is the only heat labile antibody.

* Increased levels are seen in a defect of the CD40 ligand.

* Involved in vertical transmission from mother to fetus in Rubella.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a pentameric immunoglobulin, hence it is an IgM antibody.

IgM antibody is the first antibody released in response to any antigen. It is released in the form of a pentamer and has 10 antigen-binding sites. The half-life of IgM is 5- 7 days. It is a heat-stable antibody. It is the most efficient immunoglobulin in agglutination, complement fixation, and defense against bacteria and viruses. However, it is less effective in the neutralization of toxins and viruses compared to IgG. It does not cross the placenta.

Reaction

IgG

IgM

Neutralization

Strong

Weak

Agglutination

Weak

Strong

Complement fixation

Moderate

Strong


IgE is the only heat-labile antibody.

Clinical correlate:

* Because of their short half-lives, the presence of IgM antibodies indicates a recent infection.

* It cannot cross the placenta. Therefore, the presence of this antibody indicates intrauterine infection.

* Hyper IgM syndrome is a syndrome where there are high levels of IgM with very low levels of IgG and IgA. It occurs due to a deficiency of the CD40 ligand. CD40L is expressed on T cells and is required to induce B cells to undergo class-switching from IgM to IgG and IgA.



Pearl PM2056: Properties of immunoglobulin classes

IgG:

* Half-life- 23 days

* Appears late, indicates chronic infection

* It is the only maternal Ig to cross the placenta.

* Has 4 subclasses.

* Facilitates opsonization (via Fc receptor binding)

* Causes complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of toxins and viruses.

IgM:

* Half-life- 5 days

* Has the highest molecular weight and is a pentamer.

* Polysaccharides and lipids mainly stimulate IgM secretion.

* Intravascular distribution.

* Appears early, indicates recent infection.

* Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.

* It causes agglutination, hemolysis, complement fixation and opsonization.

IgD:

* Half-life- 2-8 days.

* Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.

* Serves as recognition receptors for antigens.

IgE:

* Half-life- 1-5 days

* Causes type I hypersensitivity.

* It is the only heat-labile antibody.

* Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

IgA:

* Half-life- 6 days

* It is of 2 types- Serum IgA and Secretory IgA 

* Secretory IgA (A dimer) results in mucosal immunity.

Pearl PM0536: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

questions.text: 2. What is the disease caused by the parasite whose life cycle is given below?
questions.solution:
The given life cycle shows a tick and intra-erythrocytic stages, which are typical of babesia/piroplasmosis.

Babesia is transmitted to humans or other mammals through the bite of nymphal Ixodid ticks, the definitive host. The infective sporozoites in the tick salivary glands enter the bloodstream, transform into trophozoites in red blood cells, multiply asexually, rupture the erythrocytes, and invade new ones, while some develop into gametocytes.

When a female tick feeds on an infected host, it ingests the gametocytes, which multiply sexually in the tick's gut and later migrate to the salivary glands, where they divide into smaller forms called vermicules. The vermicules undergo secondary schizogony to produce sporozoites, completing the cycle. In humans, merogony occurs in red blood cells, whereas sporogony occurs in ticks. Transmission can also occur via blood transfusion, and transovarian passage maintains the parasite in tick populations

On microscopic examination of blood films by Giemsa stain, Babesia trophozoites appear as intraerythrocytic round or pyriform or ring form. The ring form is the most common, and it lacks the central hemozoin deposit, which differentiates it from P. falciparum. Other distinguishing features are the absence of schizonts and gametocytes and the presence of tetrads/ maltese crosses, which are pathognomic of B. microti or B. duncani.

The image given below shows the maltese cross appearance seen in infection with Babesia microti



Other options:

Option A: Anaplasma causes human granulocyte anaplasmosis. It is transmitted by ticks. The image below shows a morula of Anaplasma in a granulocyte. The life cycle in question shows tick-borne disease with intraerythrocytic life stages, not intra-leukocytic stages.



Option B: Ehrlichia chaffeensis is a gram-negative, obligate intracellular bacterium that is transmitted by hard ticks. It infects monocytes preferably. The image below shows a morula of Ehrlichia in a monocyte.



Option D: Borreliosis is caused by Borrelia species. Borreliosis (Lyme disease / Relapsing fever) is an infection caused by Borrelia species, which are spirochetes transmitted to humans by ticks (Ixodes for Lyme disease) or lice (for louse-borne relapsing fever). Humans act as an intermediate host. There is no intraerythrocytic stage in their life cycle.

questions.text: 3. A 25-year-old man with a history of consumption of raw crabs presents with headache, fever, and neck stiffness. CSF analysis revealed increased eosinophils and Giemsa-stained larvae and adult worms. MRI shows no cysts. Which of the following helminths can be implicated in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a man with consumption of raw crabs, clinical features suggestive of meningitis, and CSF analysis showing eosinophilia and Giemsa-stained adult worms, who is diagnosed with eosinophilic meningitis, is suggestive of Angiostrongylus cantonensis infection. 

It is also called a rat lungworm since it usually presents in the pulmonary artery of rats. The adult worm is 20mm long and 0.3mm thick, and the eggs resemble those of hookworms. Rarely, it may show ocular involvement. Natural hosts are rats, intermediate hosts include molluscs, crabs, and crayfish, while the infective form to man is the L3 larvae. The life cycle is given below:



Diagnosis and Treatment: Peripheral eosinophilia and high CSF eosinophilia are constant features, where larvae and adult worms can be seen in CSF fluid. Most cases recover spontaneously with supportive therapy and corticosteroids. Antihelminthic drugs' effectiveness is uncertain and should not be used independently of steroid cover as this may worsen the condition. Repeated lumbar puncture may provide some relief. 

 Nematodes with crabs and crayfish as a source of infection

* Angiostrongylus cantonensis

* Paragonimus westermani

Parasites found in CSF

* Protozoa like Trypanosoma brucei sp, Naegleria fowleri, and Acanthamoeba sp. 

* Helminths- Angiostrongylus cantonensis.

Other options:

Option A: Ancylostoma braziliense causes cutaneous larva migrans. The infection is acquired from dog or cat feces in soil. It is not usually associated with eosinophilic meningitis. 

Option B: Strongyloides stercoralis causes larva currens, which presents with a rapidly advancing skin lesion. It is not usually associated with eosinophilic meningitis. 

Option D: Taenia solium, causing neurocysticercosis, can cause eosinophilic meningitis, but the MRI will show cysts.

questions.text: 4. Bone marrow aspirate of a patient shows the following features. Which of the following is true?

choices.text: Buffy coat is used to diagnose the parasite
It is an obligate extracellular parasite
Stibogluconate is the first line of treatment in India

questions.solution:
The given image shows the amastigote form of leishmaniasis located intracellularly in macrophages. Buffy coat is used to diagnose the parasite.

Visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar) is a slowly progressing indigenous disease caused by a protozoan parasite of genus Leishmania. Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disorder transmitted by the bite of an infected female Phlebotomus sandfly(OptionC) in developing countries. The disease is transmitted by sand flies, which inoculate the flagellated promastigotes into the skin of the host.

In human beings, the disease presents in four different forms with a broad range of clinical manifestation:

* Visceral leishmaniasis, or kala-azar,

* Cutaneous leishmaniasis,

* Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis, and

* Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis.

The life cycle of Leishmania involves two forms,

* The promastigote which develops and lives extracellularly in the sandfly vector and

* The amastigote which multiplies intracellularly in the reticuloendothelial cells of the host (Option B)

It lowers immunity, causes persistent fever, anemia, liver and spleen enlargement, and if left untreated, death may occur due to opportunistic infection.

Diagnosis:

* Rapid diagnostic test: rK39 Rapid diagnostic test and Kala azar dipstick test strip.

* Parasitological diagnosis: Demonstration of LD bodies in buffy coat smear - confirmatory.

* Aldehyde test of Napier: Widely used for surveillance.

* Serological tests for diagnosis: Rapid dipstick test, Direct agglutination test, ELISA, Indirect Fluorescent Antibody Test

* Leishmanin (Montenegro) test: Induration of 5mm or more is considered positive, usually positive 4-6 weeks after onset in cutaneous leishmaniasis, valuable for distinguishing immune from nonimmune subjects and endemicity.

Drugs used in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis are sodium stibogluconate, miltefosine, and amphotericin. Liposomal amphotericin single dose 10mg/Kg IV is the first line of treatment in India(Option D)

Pearl PM1757: Various morphological stages of hemoflagellates

It is based on the arrangement of the flagella in relation to the position of the nucleus and its point of emergence from the cells.



Stage Morphological characteristics Seen in
Amastigote

Rounded or ovoid, without any external flagellum.

The nucleus, kinetoplast, and axial filaments can be seen.

The axoneme extends up to the anterior end of the cell

 Trypanosoma cruzi and Leishmania as the intracellular form in the vertebrate host.
Promastigote

Lanceolate in shape.

Antenuclear kinetoplast- kinetoplast is anterior to the nucleus near the anterior end of the cell, from which flagellum emerges.

There is no undulating membrane

 It is the infective stage of Leishmania, found in the insect vector as well as in cultures in­vitro.
Epimastigote

Elongated. 

Juxtanuclear kinetoplast - kinetoplast placed more posteriorly, close to and in front of the nucleus.

The flagellum runs alongside the body as a short undulating membrane, before emerging from the anterior end.

It is the form in which Trypanosoma brucei occurs in the salivary gland of the vector tsetse fly and Trypanosoma cruzi in the midgut of the vector reduviid bug.

Note: This stage is lacking in Leishmania.
Trypo-mastigote

This stage is elongated, spindle-shaped with a central nucleus.

Postnuclear kinetoplast - kinetoplast is posterior to the nucleus and situated at the posterior end of the body.

The flagellum runs alongside the entire length of the cell to form a long undulating membrane before emerging as a free flagellum from the anterior end.

This is the infective stage of trypanosomes found in arthropod vector and in the blood of an infected vertebrate.

Note: This stage is lacking in Leishmania.

questions.text: 5. A researcher is conducting an epidemiological investigation into a contaminated swimming pool. He uses a bacteriocin typing-based technique to type the various strains of the bacterium that secrete pyocin. Which organism is implicated in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Pyocins are bacteriocins produced by Pseudomonas.

Bacteriocins are highly specific antibiotic-like substances produced by a bacterium that inhibit the growth of other strains of the same bacterium or different species. The process of bacteriocin typing is dependent on the produced bacteriocin’s ability to kill standard indicator strains.

Mechanism of action of Bacteriocins: They act either by inducing pores in the cell membrane of susceptible bacteria or by inducing degradation of their DNA via DNAse enzyme. 

Method of bacteriocin typing: The test bacterium is streaked broadly in the center of an agar plate. After growth, the bacterial cells are removed, and the remaining cells are killed using chloroform vapor. Standard indicator strains are then streaked perpendicular to the original inoculum. Following incubation, the resulting pattern of inhibition of the indicator strains is used to determine the bacteriocin type of the test bacterium.

Bacterial typing is done for intra-species strain characterization during outbreaks.

Other options:

Shigella sonnei (option A), E.coli (option C), and other members of the Enterobacteriaceae produce colistin. While Staphylococcus aureus (Option D) produces lysostaphins.

questions.text: 6. A new research laboratory has been built with maximum containment facilities. The lab handles life-threatening pathogens that have no available treatment or vaccine and are transmitted via aerosols. Which Biosafety Level (BSL) does this facility represent, and which of the following pathogens is handled here?
questions.solution:
The given scenario represents a Biosafety Level 4 (BSL-4) facility, which handles organisms with no available treatment or vaccine, such as the Ebola virus.

The table below shows the different biosafety levels and the organisms handled by them:

BSL Level

Examples of Organisms Handled

BSL-1 (basic teaching labs, non-pathogens)

E. coli (non-pathogenic lab strain), Bacillus subtilis, Saccharomyces cerevisiae

BSL-2 (moderate risk)

Salmonella Typhi, Shigella, Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), Hepatitis B virus, HIV, Dengue virus, Vibrio

BSL-3 (high risk, treatable)

Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Coxiella burnetii, Yersinia pestis, Bacillus anthracis, SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19)

BSL-4 (maximum containment, no cure/vaccine)

Ebola virus, Marburg virus, Lassa fever virus, Nipah virus, Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus, Variola


Pearl PM2458: Laboratory Biosafety Levels (BSL)

 

Biosafety level Lab practices Safety Equipment Facility
BSL 1

Work on open lab benches or tables.

Good microbiological techniques followed

 PPE (lab coats, gloves, eye protection) are worn as needed.

Sink for hand washing.

Separate doors from the rest of the facility.
BSL 2 Access restricted to the laboratory

Appropriate PPE (lab coats, gloves, eye protection, and face shields).

Biological safety cabinets (BSC) to prevent potential aerosols.

Autoclave or alternative method for decontamination

Sink and eyewash easily available.

Self-closing doors. 
BSL 3

Access restricted and controlled at all times.

Medical surveillance of laboratory workers.

Appropriate PPE must be worn, and respirators might be required.

BSC for all activities.

Hands-free sink and eyewash.

Directional airflow from clean areas towards potentially contaminated areas.

Entrance to the lab is through 2 self-closing and interlocked doors.
BSL 4

Change clothing before entering and shower upon exiting.

Decontaminate all materials before exiting.

BSC and full-body, air-supplied, positive pressure suit.

Double-ended autoclave (through the wall).

Laboratory in a separate building or isolated in a restricted zone.

Dedicated supply and exhaust air, as well as vacuum lines and decontamination systems.

questions.text: 7. A 10-year-old child is brought to your clinic with complaints of diarrhea and abdominal pain for the past 4 days. Stool microscopy is shown below. The eggs present in the stool float in a saturated solution of salt. What is the most likely organism implicated?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the egg seen on stool microscopy are suggestive of infection with Hymenolepis nana. 

The Hymenolepis nana eggs have a thin colorless outer membrane and an inner embryophore enclosing the hexacanth oncosphere. The space between two membranes contains yolk granules and thread-like polar filaments arising from two knobs on the embryophore. The eggs are non-bile stained and float in a saturated salt solution.

Hymenolepis nana is the smallest tapeworm. Man is the host. The patient acquires this infection by ingesting food or water contaminated with eggs of these organisms. The adult work resides in the small intestine.

Hymenolepiasis occurs more commonly in children. They are usually asymptomatic. In heavy infections, they present with nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and irritability. Sometimes pruritus may be present due to an allergic response. A single dose of praziquantel (25 mg/kg) is the drug of choice.

The image given below shows the egg of Hymenolepis nana.



Other options:

Option A- The fertilized eggs of Ascaris lumbricoides are bile stained and float in a saturated solution of water. They are round or oval in shape. The egg is surrounded by a thick smooth translucent shell having a coarsely mamillated translucent coat. In the middle of the egg, there is a large unsegmented ovum. It covers the entire area of the egg, except for the poles.

Unfertilized eggs do not float in salt solution. They are long, narrow, and elliptical in shape. They have thinner shell with irregular albumin coating and small atrophied ovum.

The left image is unfertilized egg, while the right is the fertilized egg of Ascaris.



Option B- The eggs of the Ancylostoma duodenale are non-bile stained and float in a saturated salt solution. It has a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane and a segmented ovum containing 4-8 blastomeres. The space between the hyaline shell and the ovum is clear. 

The image given below shows the egg of Ancylostoma sp.



Option D- Eggs of Trichuris trichiura are brown in color, bile stained, and float in a saturated salt solution. They are barrel-shaped, with a mucus plug on either end. 

The image given below shows the egg of Trichuris trichiura

questions.text: 9. Which among the following organisms show stately motility?
questions.solution:
Clostridium shows stately motility.

Clostridia have peritrichate flagella and motility is slow, described as stately. Of the Clostridium species, Clostridium perfringens and Clostridium tetani type VI are non-motile.

questions.text: 10. A patient recently returned from a tour to Egypt and presents with painless haematuria. This structure was found on microscopy of urine. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the life cycle of the causative organism?

choices.text: Cercaria larva are the infective form
Metacercaria stage is seen in the snail

questions.solution:
Eggs with terminal spine and a history of painless hematuria are suggestive of infection with Schistosoma haematobium. Metacercaria stage is not seen in schistosomes.

Schistosoma eggs are ovoid, about 150 μm by 50 μm, non-operculated, with a brownish-yellow transparent shell carrying a characteristic terminal spine at one pole. Schistosoma haematobium primarily causes genito-urinary schistosomiasis. The adult worms live in the veins of urinary bladder.

Cercaria larva are the infective form of schistosomes. Cercaria infects man by penetrating the skin which can lead to intense irritation and skin rash at the site of cercarial penetration (known as swimmer's itch).

After penetrating the skin, the cercariae lose their tails and become schistosomulae which travel through peripheral venules to systemic circulation, to the inferior mesenteric veins, finally reaching the vesical and pelvic venous plexuses, where they mature and lay eggs. The eggs that are passed in urine are embryonated and hatch in water under suitable conditions to release the free-living ciliated miracidia.

Miracidia penetrates into tissues of the snail and reaches its liver. Large numbers of cercariae are produced by asexual reproduction and are released into the water. Metacercaria and redia stages are not seen in schistosomes.

Praziquantel is the drug of choice for schistosomiasis.

The following are the unique features distinguishing schistosomes from other trematodes:

* Only one intermediate host

* They produce non- operculated eggs.

* They have no redia stage in larval development

* Mode of infection is by penetration of intact skin with the help of forked tails of cercariae

* Schistosomes are dioecious, sexes are separate.

NOTE: Infective forms of most trematodes (Eg. Fasciola hepatica, Fasciola buski, Clonorchis sinensis) to humans are metacercaria larva.



Species differentiation of Schistosoma can be done based on the location of spine as follows.

* Terminal spine: Schistosoma hematobium

* Lateral spine: Schistosoma mansoni

* Round with small lateral knob or Rudimentary spine: Schistosoma japonicum.

Pearl PM1759: Eggs of Schistosoma

questions.text: 12. A chronic alcoholic male patient presents with nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. Stool examination revealed the eggs of Balantidium coli. What is the organ of locomotion for this organism?
questions.solution:
The organ of locomotion for Balantidium coli is the cilia. 

Balantidium coli is the only ciliated protozoan and is present as a commensal in the large intestine. It does not cause infection in healthy individuals. However, certain predisposing factors such as malnourishment, alcoholism, concurrent infection with Trichuris trichiura, or bacterial infection can cause clinical infection.

Clinical patients present with mucosal ulcers, diarrhea, frank dysentery, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. 

Diagnosis is by stool examination, which shows the presence of trophozoites in diarrheic feces and cysts in formed stools. Trophozoites are large size, with a macronucleus and rapid-revolving motility, while cysts are round with a macronucleus.

The image given below shows trophozoite of Balantidium coli.

questions.text: 13. Which of the following is true about the form of Toxoplasma shown below?

choices.text: It develops only in the definitive host
It is often associated with chronicity
It frequently infects red blood cells

questions.solution:
The image shows a tachyzoite/trophozoite of Toxoplasma, which replicates by endogyny or internal budding. 

Tachyzoites are the rapidly dividing trophozoites in the acute stage of infection. They can invade any nucleated cell (option C) and replicate within parasitophorous vacuoles by endogyny/internal budding. Two daughter trophozoites thus formed are surrounded by an independent membrane while still within the parent cell. When the host cell reaches a critical mass, it disintegrates, releasing the trophozoites that infect other cells.

Trophozoites are crescent-shaped with a pointed apex and a round base, usually measuring 3- 7 μm. They stain strongly with Giemsa and showcase a blue cytoplasm and a red nucleus. 

The asexual cycle, i.e., schizogony, is represented by trophozoites and tissue cysts, while the oocyst is formed by sexual reproduction (gametogony or sporogony).

Both asexual reproduction (schizogony) and sexual reproduction (gametogony) occur within definitive hosts such as cats (OptionA). But only the asexual forms, i.e., tachyzoites, and tissue cysts are present in intermediate hosts such as humans, mice, rats, etc.

The life cycle is given below





Option A: It develops only in the definitive host. This is false since tachyzoites are found in the asexual phase of the cycle, which occurs in both the definitive and the intermediate hosts. 

Option B: Tachyzoites are associated with acute disease,not chronic infection. Weakly PAS+ Tissue cysts containing strongly PAS+ bradyzoites are present in the chronic stage of infection. 

Option C: Trophozoites infect nucleated cells. RBCs are anucleate and are thus not infected by them.

questions.solution:
The above image shows the autoclave machine. It is a method of sterilization by moist heat.

questions.text: 15. A 35-year-old man from a filariasis-endemic region presents with recurrent fever and lymphadenopathy. Which of the following techniques can be used to concentrate and detect microfilariae in the blood of this man?
questions.solution:
The technique that can be used to concentrate and detect microfilariae in the blood is Knott’s centrifugation technique.

Knott’s concentration technique is a quantitative method used to detect and count microfilariae in blood. It involves lysing red blood cells with 2% formalin, then centrifuging the sample, and staining the sediment (commonly with Giemsa).

This method increases sensitivity compared to a direct smear, especially in low parasitemia.

Membrane filtration concentration is another concentration technique. Membrane filtration concentration for filaria involves passing lysed blood through a 3 µm membrane filter, which traps microfilariae while allowing red cells and debris to pass. The membrane is then stained and examined microscopically, providing a sensitive method to detect and quantify microfilariae.    Other concentration techniques used for the detection of microfilariae are- Sedimentation technique, Cytocentrifugation (cytospin), and Gradient centrifugation.

Other Options

Option B: The Baermann technique is a diagnostic method used to recover live nematode larvae from fecal material or soil.

Option C: Although a thick blood smear can be used for a quick check, it is not sensitive enough to detect low microfilarial burdens. Furthermore, it does not concentrate the microfilariae and is not ideal for detailed morphological studies.

Option D: Quantitative buffy coat (QBC): A method that uses a specialized capillary tube coated with acridine orange (a fluorescent stain) to concentrate and stain parasites, which are then visualized under a fluorescent microscope.

questions.text: 16. The life cycle of a parasite is shown below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this parasitic infection?

choices.text: The parasite belongs to the phylum Nematoda
Feces examination is not commonly used in diagnosis
The alimentary canal of the parasite is incomplete, without an anus
The eggs of the parasite are  colorless and non-bile stained

questions.solution:
The given life cycle is indicative of Enterobius vermicularis, and the incorrect statement is its alimentary canal is incomplete, without an anus.

The nematode Enterobius vermicularis has an alimentary canal that is complete till the anus. It causes perianal pruritis. Eggs are present in the feces only in a small proportion of patients, so feces examination is not useful in diagnosis. NIH swab method and Scotch tape method are used for the collection of specimens. This involves pressing an adhesive cellophane tape against the perianal region early in the morning and transferring it to a glass slide under the microscope to demonstrate eggs.

Pinworm eggs are planoconvex with a double-layered eggshell that is relatively thick and transparent. The are colorless, non-bile stained. They float in the saturated salt solution. Treatment includes albendazole.

The life cycle of Enterobius vermicularis is given below.

questions.text: 17. A microbiology slide shows a parasite, as shown in the image given below. What is the definitive host of this parasite?
questions.solution:
The organism shown in the image is Taenia solium, and its definitive host is man.

The image shows a scolex with 4 suckers and 2 rows of hooks, which is characteristic of Taenia solium.

T. solium mainly causes two forms of infection in humans:

Intestinal taeniasis- Adult tapeworms in the intestine. It results when raw or undercooked meats containing the cysticerci are ingested. Intestinal taeniasis may be asymptomatic with the passage of proglottids in the feces.

Cysticercosis- Larva forms in the tissues. It results from the ingestion of food or water contaminated with eggs or by auto-infection from the eggs that are laid in the intestine. In cysticercosis, the cysticerci are most commonly detected in the brain, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), skeletal muscle, subcutaneous tissue, or eye.

The adult worm has a scolex with four suckers and a rostellum with hooks. The rostellum and hooks are absent in the case of T.saginata. Man is generally the definitive host and the intermediate host is usually a pig, but occasionally it can be a man. Since humans carry larvae or eggs or both, they are considered both intermediate and definitive hosts.

The life cycle of T. soleum is shown below:



The eggs of T. solium are infective to man and pigs. The eggs of T. saginata are infective only to cattle and not to man. The eggs of Taenia solium do not float in the saturated salt solution and are bile-stained.

Neurocysticercosis is the most common form of cysticercosis, presenting with seizures, and symptoms of increased intracranial pressure including headache, nausea, vomiting, vision changes, dizziness, ataxia, or confusion. Papilledema may develop secondary to hydrocephalus.

Diagnosis is by fecal examination showing eggs of Taenia. Biopsy of the brain or spinal cord lesion showing parasite or fundoscopic visualization of subretinal cysticercus can be done. 

Imaging could demonstrate a scolex within a cystic lesion, cystic lesions with or without enhancement (e.g., ring enhancement), nodular calcifications, focal enhancing lesions, or multilobulated cystic lesions in the subarachnoid space.

Treatment of intestinal T. solium infection is by a single dose of praziquantel. Neurocysticercosis is treated with anti-epileptic drugs, anticysticidal drugs like albendazole or praziquantel, and steroids given before anticysticidal therapy.

The image given below shows the scolex of T. saginata. The scolex is quadrate in outline and has four circular suckers. Rostellum and hooklets are absent (i.e. unarmed scolex).

questions.text: 18. A 30-year-old truck driver with history of unprotected intercourse presented with a painless ulcer in the genital area. All of the following are used to demonstrate the causative organism, except?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is most suggestive of syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum. Castenada's method is used to culture organisms under the genus Brucella.

Syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum, which is a spirochete bacillus. Morphologically, the organism is a thin spirochete with tapering ends and shows corkscrew motility. The name 'pallidum' comes from the fact it is pale staining and cannot be visualized under a light microscope. T. pallidum can be demonstrated by darkfield microscopy with negative staining, or by silver impregnation methods, which are Fontana's method for smears and Levaditi's method for tissue sections





Serologic tests for syphilis recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC):

Screening or diagnosis (RPR or VDRL), Quantitative measurement of antibody to assess clinical syphilis activity or to monitor response to therapy (RPR or VDRL) Confirmation of a syphilis diagnosis in a patient with a reactive RPR or VDRL test (FTA-ABS, TPHA, EIA/CIA)

Treatment of syphilis is with 2.4 million units of intramuscular benzathine penicillin.

Pearl PM1786: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  


 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.


C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration


Pearl PM2340: Stages of syphilis

Primary syphilis:

* Chancre - Painless, indurated, usually single. The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.

* Lymphadenopathy - Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes

* Dory flop sign - As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

Secondary syphilis:



* A & B: Generalized non-itchy rash with no vesicles present on the palm and sole. This is the most common lesion.

* C & D: Condyloma lata.

* E: Moth-eaten non-scarring alopecia

* F: Mucous patches are flat erosions on the tongue that can coalesce to form snail track ulcers. These are the most infectious lesions.

* G: Pigmentary plaques

* H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions

* Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

Tertiary syphilis:

* Gummatous syphilis are deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor

* Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  

* CVS - Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta

* CNS - General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

Latent syphilis is the period between secondary and tertiary syphilis. In this period the patient is asymptomatic clinically and only serological evidence of the infection is present. It is classified into:

* Early latent syphilis - Within 1 year of infection

* Late latent syphilis - After 1 year of infection

questions.text: 19. A patient presents with a cough with rusty sputum and fever for the past few weeks. She gives a history of recent travel to Japan and the consumption of undercooked crayfish. A complete blood count reveals eosinophilia. All of the following are true about this condition, except ______.

choices.text: It is a food-borne trematode infection
Eggs are coughed up in sputum
Embryonated eggs are the infective form
Praziquantel is the treatment of choice

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of infection with Paragonimus westermani (lung fluke). All the given options are true about this condition, except that embryonated eggs are the infective form.

Metacercariae encysted in crab or crayfish is the infective form.

P. westermani is a trematode. Transmission to humans occurs by eating raw or undercooked crab or crayfish containing metacercariae. The metacercariae encyst in the human gut and young worms migrate to the lungs, where they become encapsulated in lung tissue.

The patient complains of cough, chest pain, and hemoptysis. The viscous sputum is speckled with golden-brown eggs.

Treatment: Praziquantel (25 mg/kg TDS for 1–2 days) is the drug of choice.

The following image shows the life cycle of P. westermani, the oriental lung fluke.

questions.text: 20. You are working in the ICU of a local hospital. The hospital reports a high number of hospital-acquired infections. Which of the following practice will you adopt apart from hand hygiene to prevent hospital-acquired infection?

choices.text: Wearing a surgical mask before doing a spinal tap
Washing gloves with sanitiser before examining the next patient
Using a multi-dose vial for multiple patients
Capping the syringe needle immediately after use, to avoid needle stick injury

questions.solution:
A surgical mask should be worn before placing a catheter or doing a spinal tap.

Other infection control practices are:

* 5 moments of Hand hygiene - before doing aseptic procedure, before and after touching a patient, even if gloves are to be worn, after contact with body fluids, after touching patient surroundings.

* Gloves should not be washed for the purpose of reuse (Option B).

* Wearing a gown if body fluid contact is anticipated, using one gown for one patient only.

* To not cap needles after use, as needlestick injury occurs while capping (Option D). Instead, dispose of the needle in a needle burner or cutter.

* Single-use vials, ampoules, bottles, and fluid administration sets are to be used for one patient only. A syringe should not be reused, even for a single vial.

* Avoid usage of multi-dose vials for more than one patient (Option C).

questions.text: 21. Albert staining of Corynebacterium diphtheria would reveal:

choices.text: Bluish-black metachromatic granules  and green bacillary body
Green metachromatic granules  and Bluish-black bacillary body
Dark green metachromatic granules  and light green bacillary body
Dark blue metachromatic granules  and light blue bacillary body

questions.solution:
Bluish-black metachromatic granules and green bacillary bodies are seen with Albert's staining of Corynebacterium diptheriae.

Albert's stain contains toluidine blue 'O' and malachite green which have an affinity for acidic cytoplasm, both being basic dyes. Albert’s stain, Neisser’s, and Ponder’s stain are used to demonstrate the metachromatic granules (Volutin / Babes Ernst Granules) of Corynebacterium diphtheria.

 Procedure for Albert's staining:

* A heavy smear of the bacterial isolate is prepared on a glass slide and allowed to dry without fixing.

* Albert’s stain is applied for (3-4) minutes then it is washed with water and Albert’s iodine is applied for one minute.

* Wash with water and let it dry with blotting paper.

Results:

* Metachromatic granules: Bluish-black

* Bacillary body or protoplasm: Green

Uses: 

* Albert staining is useful in the demonstration of metachromatic granules.

* The presence of metachromatic granules helps to distinguish C.diphtheriae from diphtheriods which lack them.

Image shows Albert's stain of C. diphtheria



Pearl PM1786: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  


 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.


C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: 22. A 17-year-old swimmer presents to your OPD with blurred vision and severe pain in the left eye. On slit-lamp examination, a paracentral ring-shaped lesion is seen. Staining of corneal scraping showed the following finding. What is the drug of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for the given clinical vignette is Polyhexamethyl biguanide 0.02%. The clinical vignette of a swimmer with a ring-shaped lesion of the cornea and the image depicting cyst of Acanthamoeba in lactophenol cotton blue staining is suggestive of Acanthamoeba keratitis.

Acanthamoeba is a free-living amoeba. It exists as a trophozoite form and a resistant cystic form. Both these forms are infectious. The trophozoite is large and characterized by spine-like pseudopodia (acanthopodia). Human beings acquire the infection by inhalation of cysts or trophozoites, ingestion of cysts, or through traumatised skin or eyes.

It presents as two chronic conditions - acanthamoeba keratitis and granulomatous amoebic encephalitis.

Acanthamoeba keratitis, a rare protozoal corneal infection, primarily affects soft contact lens users who wash lenses with tap water. Other sources include swimming/hot tub use with lenses, homemade saline, and standing groundwater exposure.

 A key diagnostic feature is pain disproportionate to the degree of keratitis, due to perineural invasion. The condition can present as a ring lesion (the most common), pseudo-dendrites, or a reticular pattern. 

Diagnosis involves staining (calcofluor white, acridine orange, lactophenol blue) and culture on non-nutrient agar with E. coli overlay. Confocal microscopy can identify trophozoites and double-walled cysts, while histopathology reveals double-walled cysts with H&E and other specific stains.

Treatments include diamidines, aminoglycosides, and imidazoles. Combination therapy with chlorhexidine and polyhexamethylene biguanide (PHMB) is the most effective first-line recommendation.

The image below shows the ring lesions seen in Acanthamoeba keratitis



The image below double-walled cysts of acanthamoeba in normal H&E staining in a patient with the advanced brain disease



The image below shows the corneal scrapings with multiple cysts of Acanthamoeba on a plain mount.



Other options:

Option A: Fluorometholone 0.5% (Option 1) is a treatment option for marginal keratitis and spring catarrh which is caused by a hypersensitivity reaction against staphylococcal exotoxins which causes subepithelial marginal infiltrates.

Option B:Topical cyclosporine 1% (Option 2) is a treatment option for Mooren's ulcer which is an autoimmune disease characterized by peripheral corneal stromal ulceration with subsequent central spread.

Option C:Doxycycline (Option 3) is a treatment option for ocular rosacea which may have corneal manifestations that include epithelial erosions, marginal keratitis, corneal thinning and perforation.

questions.text: 23. A patient presents with dry nocturnal cough, dyspnea, and wheezing. The eosinophil count is markedly increased, along with high levels of serum IgE and filarial antibodies. Following treatment with diethylcarbamazine, he developed pruritus, rash, lymphadenopathy, fever, and hypotension. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario given above is suggestive of tropical pulmonary eosinophilia, which is a manifestation of occult filariasis. Following treatment with diethylcarbamazine (DEC), a severe allergic reaction, known as the Mazzotti reaction, may occur. 

Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia presents with low-grade fever, weight loss, and pulmonary symptoms like a dry nocturnal cough, dyspnea, and wheezing. There is a rise in the eosinophil count, IgE, and filarial antibodies. Diethylcarbamazine is the drug of choice for filariasis (option D) and is given orally.

Mazzotti reaction occurs due to the release of antigens from the death of microfilariae and is not an allergic response to DEC(Option C).  It presents as pruritus, rash, lymphadenopathy, fever, and hypotension occurring after the administration drug. The Mazzotti reaction if develops is treated symptomatically with antipyretics, antihistamines, and antihypotensive agents and can be prevented by using steroids.

Other options:

Option A: Jarisch–Herxheimer reaction is a transient clinical phenomenon that occurs in patients infected with spirochetes like syphilis, leptospirosis, Lyme disease, and relapsing fever, who are treated with antibiotics. The reaction occurs within 24 hours of antibiotic therapy. It generally manifests as fever, chills, rigors, nausea and vomiting, tachycardia, hypotension, flushing, myalgia, and exacerbation of skin lesions. It is an acute, self-limiting condition.

questions.text: 24. Which of the following components are produced by the Th1 cells?
questions.solution:
Interleukin-2 and interferon-γ are produced by the Th1 cells. 

CD 4+ cells become one of the following effector cells. They are Th1 cells, Th2 cells, Th17 cells, Tfh cells, or T regulatory (T reg) cells.

Th1 cells: These cells are triggered in response to interleukin-2 and interleukin-12. They cause activation of macrophages and cause B cells to switch into different classes of IgG. This leads to the direct destruction of the bacterial cells and their clearance by the interferon-γ-activated macrophages or by the phagocytosis of opsonized particles. Th1 cells produce interleukin-2 and interferon-γ.

Other options:

Option B- Interleukin-4 and interleukin-5 are produced by the Th2 cells. Th2 cells also secrete interleukins-9 and 13. These cells cause the activation of mast cells and eosinophils. They stimulate B cells to produce IgE. These cells are helpful in protecting patients from helminth infections.

Option C- Interleukins 21, 22, and 17 are produced from the Th17 cells. Th17 cells are produced in response to transforming growth factor-β, interleukins-6 and 23. Interleukin-17 induces the production of interleukin-8, which is a potent chemotactic factor.

Option D- Transforming growth factor-β and interleukin-10 are produced by the T reg cells. These chemokines suppress the immune responses.

questions.text: 25. After inoculating an organism on Hugh-Leifson's medium, a microbiologist observes a reaction as shown below in the image. Which is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
The image shows fermentative utilization of glucose on Hugh-Leifson’s medium, which is shown by Staphylococcus aureus.

Hugh-Leifson’s oxidative-fermentative test uses a semi-solid medium with carbohydrate and a pH indicator (bromothymol blue). Two tubes are inoculated per organism:

* Oil-covered (anaerobic) tube: tests for fermentation

* Open (aerobic) tube: tests oxidation

Acid production from carbohydrate metabolism turns the medium yellow. Alkaline or unchanged color signifies no fermentation/oxidation.

The image below shows the growth of various organisms on Hugh-Leifson’s medium:



Test tube set-1 shows no change of green to yellow, signifying the growth of non-saccharolytic organisms. E.g., Acinobacter spp.

Test tube set-2 shows a change of green colour to yellow, but only in the open (aerobic) tube, signifying the growth of strict aerobes. E.g., Pseudomonas (Option A), Brucella (Option B), Bordetella, Nocardia (Option D).

Test tube set-3 shows a change of green colour to yellow in both the aerobic and anaerobic tubes, signifying the growth of facultative anaerobes. E.g., Enterobacteriaceae, Staphylococci, Streptococci.

questions.text: 26. A female patient presented to the OPD with a history of progressive breathlessness and cough for 3 months. A chest X-ray showed a cavitary lesion in the lower lobe of the right lung and the cut section of the infective agent is given below. Which part of the infective agent is used while performing Casoni's intradermal test?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, it points towards the diagnosis of hydatid disease of the lung caused by Echinococcus granulosus. Casoni's intradermal test is used to diagnose this condition and uses fresh, sterile hydatid fluid (3) from hydatid cysts. 

Casoni’s intradermal test is a type I hypersensitivity test . It involves the intradermal injection of 0.25 mL of sterile fluid from hydatid cysts into the forearm. An equal volume of saline is injected into the other forearm as a control. It is observed for the next 30 minutes and again after 1-2 days. A wheal response at the injection site occurring within 20 minutes is considered positive. It is followed by a secondary reaction 8 hours later.



Hydatid disease or echinococcosis is a zoonotic infection caused by the Echinococcus species of flatworms. Its life cycle consists of the dog (optimal host) and wolf as the definitive hosts, sheep and cattle as intermediate hosts. Man acts as an accidental intermediate host (dead end).

The larval stage of the parasite is passed in intermediate hosts, including man, giving rise to a hydatid cyst which usually develops three weeks after the infection.

The hydatid cyst wall consists of 3 layers:

* Pericyst - the outer dense fibrous capsule that is formed as a result of the host's inflammatory response.

* Ectocyst - the intermediate layer consisting of acellular, chitinous, laminated hyaline material.

* Endocyst - the inner germinal layer that is cellular and consists of several nuclei embedded in a protoplasmic mass, and is extremely thin. It is the vital layer of the cyst, and it is the site of asexual reproduction, giving rise to brood capsules with scolices.

The brood capsules (1) are cellular masses in the hydatid fluid, which consists of scoleces (2). In a definitive host, these scoleces develop into adult tapeworms, while in the intermediate hosts, they develop into new hydatid cysts. The brood capsules are attached to the endocyst by a pedicle or stalk. 

The brood capsules may mature and detach from the mother cyst and become the daughter cysts, which are an exact replica of the mother cysts. The freed brood capsules and scoleces present in the hydatid fluid are called hydatid sand(4).

Hydatid disease most commonly occurs in the liver, with the second most common being the lungs. The clinical features of hydatid disease of the lung include breathlessness, cough, hemoptysis, chest pain, and even pneumothorax. Treatment includes wedge resection or lobectomy and administration of albendazole. Pre and postoperative chemotherapy with albendazole is recommended for 2 years after curative surgery.

The image below shows the histology of the hydatid cyst of the lung.



Computed tomography (CT) scan is the best imaging modality for hydatid cyst which shows the characteristic water lily sign.

The water-lily sign occurs due to detachment of the endocyst membrane from the cyst wall giving the appearance of floating membranes within the pericyst. This mimics the appearance of a water lily.



Pearl PM0658: Skin tests for the diagnosis of parasitic infections

Skin tests are performed by injecting parasitic antigen intradermally and observing the reaction. In immediate hypersensitivity reaction, wheal and flare response is seen within 30 minutes of injection, whereas in delayed type of hypersensitivity, erythema and induration are seen after 48 hours of injection.

The table below shows some of the important skin tests used in the diagnosis of parasitic infections.

questions.text: 27. All of the following methods are recommended for the sterilization of materials contaminated by prion proteins except?

choices.text: Treating with 1 N NaOH for 1 hour
Using a hot air oven at 160 °C for 1 hour
Treating with 0.5% sodium hypochlorite for 2 hours

questions.solution:
Using a hot air oven at 160 °C for 1 hour is not recommended for the sterilization of materials contaminated by prion proteins.

Prions are highly resistant to standard sterilization methods. Effective sterilization of prion-contaminated materials requires:

* Autoclaving at 134°C for 1 to 1.5 hours.

* Treating with 1 N NaOH for 1 hour.

* Treating with 0.5% sodium hypochlorite for 2 hours.

For prions bound to stainless steel, an acidic detergent solution should be applied before autoclaving to enable their inactivation.

Prions are infectious protein particles that do not contain nucleic acid. They share a characteristic with viruses in that they are filterable, but unlike viruses, prions are resistant to a broad spectrum of chemical and physical sterilization agents.

Humans, monkeys, chimpanzees

questions.text: 28. A 6-year-old boy was brought to the OPD by his mother with complaints of weight loss, malaise, weakness, and passing loose, bulky stools for the past 3 months. The pediatrician ordered a stool examination, which revealed the presence of the following organism. Which test has the best sensitivity and specificity for diagnosing this condition?
questions.solution:
ELISA has the best sensitivity and specificity to diagnose Giardia.

Giardia lamblia, contracted via infected water, causes acute or chronic diarrhoea, weight loss, malaise, cramps, distension, and weakness. Stools are watery, greasy, bulky, or foul-smelling, and notably lack blood, mucus, or faecal leukocytes. The infection is also linked to iron deficiency and growth stunting.

Diagnosis is commonly made using ELISA kits (ProSpecT/Giardia kit), which detect Giardia-specific antigen 65 (GSA 65) with great sensitivity and specificity.

Giardiasis is diagnosed via Enterotest (swallowed capsule with thread, examined after two hours in the duodenum) or microscopic examination of diarrheal stool samples for Giardia cysts and trophozoites.. Treatment options include Tinidazole and Nitazoxanide.

The above image shows the trophozoite form of Giardia lamblia which is in the shape of tennis racket or “Heart-shaped” or “pyriform shaped”.

It is bilaterally symmetrical and possesses 1 pair of nuclei, 4 pairs of flagella, 4 pairs of blepharoplast/basal bodies from which flagella arise, 1 pair of axostyles running along the midline, and 2 parabasal or median bodies.

questions.text: 29. Which of the following media contains neutral red as an indicator?
questions.solution:
Neutral red is used as an indicator in Mac-Conkey agar which is given as image 3 in the question above.

MacConkey agar is used to distinguish lactose fermenters (seen as pink colonies) from non-lactose fermenters (seen as colourless or pale). It is a selective and differential medium.

MacConkey agar is selective because bile salts and dyes inhibit Gram-positive organisms and Gram-negative cocci. It is differential because the pH indicator turns pink-red when the lactose is fermented.

Contents of MacConkey agar: Mnemonic: PLANT

P – Peptone 

L – Lactose                 

A – Agar

N – Neutral red (indicator)

T– Sodium Taurocholate

Other options

Image 1:This represents TCBS agar (Thiosulfate Citrate Bile Sucrose agar), which contains thiosulfate, citrate, bile salts, and sucrose, which is used to culture Vibrio cholerae. It ferments sucrose, forming large yellow colonies.

Image 2: This represents BCYE agar (Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract agar), which contains buffered charcoal yeast extract. It is used to culture Legionella species. Legionella are fastidious organisms that require L-cysteine and antibiotic supplements in addition to BCYE agar.

Image 4: Bordet-Gengou medium is used to culture Bordetella species, which show dome shaped, “bisected pearls/ mercury drop appearance”. Confluent growth can show an aluminium paint appearance.

Leptospira EMJH medium

questions.text: 30. Which of the following is detected by TLR-2?
questions.solution:
Gram-positive bacteria are detected by Toll-like receptors 2 or TLR 2.

Toll-like receptors (TLRs) are the microbial sensors present in the macrophages and phagocytic cells that can detect a pathogen as it enters the skin.

The mechanism is the activation of signal transduction cascade and a marked inflammatory response.   

In humans, 10 TLRs have been found which have unique microbial recognition patterns. They are as follows

* TLR 1 and 6 detect diacyl peptides 

* TLR 2 recognized various ligands like lipoteichoic acid expressed by the gram-positive bacteria

* TLR 3 engages double-stranded viral RNA in viral replication.

* TLR 4 is specific for gram-negative lipopolysaccharides.

* TLR 5 can recognize the flagellin in bacteria.

* TLR 7 and 8 interact with single-stranded RNA in viral replication.

* TLR 9 binds to both viral and bacterial DNA

* TLR 10 is an orphan receptor

questions.text: 31. Which of the following immunodiffusion tests represents single diffusion in one dimension?
questions.solution:
Single diffusion in one dimension is called the Oudin procedure. Immunodiffusion employs antigen-antibody precipitation in gel medium rather than liquid and has several advantages. 

* Distint line of precipitation which is stable and can be stained seperately

* Able to detect the number of different antigens, as individual antigens produce a distinct line of precipitation

* Analyse the identity and non-identity between different antigens

Different types of immunodiffusion:

* Single diffusion in one dimension - Oudin procedure

* Double diffusion in one dimension - Oakley-Fulthorpe procedure

* Single diffusion in two dimensions - Radial immunodiffusion/Mancini procedure : This method has been used for the estimation of the immunoglobulin classes in sera and for screening sera for antibodies to influenza viruses

* Double diffusion in two dimensions - Ouchterlony procedure : A special variety of double diffusion in two dimensions is the Elek test for toxigenicity in diphtheria bacilli. When diphtheria bacilli are streaked at right angles to a filter paper strip carrying the antitoxin implanted on a plate of suitable medium, arrowhead-shaped lines of precipitation appear on incubation, if the bacillus is toxigenic.

The images given below show the different types of immunodiffusion.

questions.text: 32. A microbiologist uses a special stain to stain the flagella of various organisms. His observations are shown in the image given below. What is the stain used and the type of arrangement of flagella, respectively, as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The stain used is Leifson-Ryu stain, and the flagellar arrangement is peritrichous.

Flagella are slender, thread-like extensions that project from the cell wall of bacteria, enabling them to move (locomote). These structures typically range from 5 to 20 µmin length and 0.01 to 0.02 µm in thickness.

Flagella can be demonstrated through:

Direct methods:

* Tannic acid staining (Leifson's method)

* Electron microscopy

Indirect methods (demonstrating motility):

* Craigie tube method

* Hanging drop method

* Semisolid medium (e.g., mannitol motility medium)

* Dark ground or phase contrast microscopy

Other Options

Option A: Schaeffer–Fulton stain is used to stain bacterial spores.

Option C: Albert’s stain is used to stain Corynebacteriae.

Option D: Levaditi–Fontana stain is used to stain spirochetes.

Pearl PM1767: Types of flagella:



Pearl PM1786: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  


 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.


C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: 33. Which of the following is used as an indicator in ethylene oxide sterilization?
questions.solution:
Bacillus atrophaeus is used as an indicator in ethylene oxide sterilization.

questions.text: 34. An infant presents with high fever, seizures, and coma, suggestive of cerebral malaria. Which of the following is most likely responsible for Plasmodium falciparum's ability to sequester in brain capillaries, contributing to neurological symptoms?

choices.text: Inflammation of blood-brain barrier by hemozoin
Infected RBCs activating the coagulation cascade

questions.solution:
Expression of Plasmodium falciparum erythrocyte membrane protein (PfEMP1) which has affinity for the brain endothelial cells causing sequestration, is the most likely mechanism. 

PfEMP1 is a highly variable protein expressed on the surface of P. falciparum-infected erythrocytes. Specific variants of PfEMP1 have a strong affinity for ICAM-1 (Intracellular Adhesion Molecule-1), which is highly expressed on endothelial cells in the brain. This adhesion leads to sequestration of infected erythrocytes in the brain capillaries, impeding blood flow and contributing to cerebral hypoxia and neurological symptoms

Other options: 

Option B: While hemozoin can contribute to inflammation, it does not directly lead to parasite sequestration.

Option C. Merozoite release occurs during erythrocyte invasion, not during sequestration.

Option D: Activation of the inflammation and the resultant coagulation cascade is not an established mechanism by which the infected RBCs are sequestered.

questions.text: 35. A patient had "Calabar swellings" and granulomas in the bulbar conjunctiva. Peripheral blood shows the following microfilaria. What is the vector for the following parasite?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a peripheral smear showing sheathed microfilaria with nuclei up to the tail tip is suggestive of Loa loa. The vector for Loa loa is Chrysops (mango fly).

Chrysops flies are day bitters and transmit third-stage larvae. The third-stage larvae reach various subcutaneous tissues and mature into adults where they reside. 

Calabar swellings are temporary foci of inflammation due to wandering parasites in subcutaneous tissues. Loa loa mainly causes ocular manifestations like granulomas in the conjunctiva, edema of eyelids etc. Thus it is also known as African eyeworm.

 The image below shows the difference between microfilaria of various filarial nematodes.

questions.text: 36. Which of the following bacteria shows lysogenic conversion by taking tox+ phage genome?
questions.solution:
The toxigenicity of the diphtheria bacillus depends on the presence of the corynephages (tox+), which act as the genetic determinant controlling the toxin production.

Non-toxigenic strains may be rendered toxigenic by infecting them with beta phage or some other phage. This is known as lysogenic or phage conversion. The toxigenicity remains only as long as the bacillus is lysogenic. When the bacillus is cured of its phage by growing it in the presence of antiphage serum, it loses the toxigenic capacity.

The diphtheria toxin disrupts protein synthesis. Fragment B facilitates its binding, while fragment A, with nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide, inactivates elongation factor EF-2, thus preventing peptide chain elongation. This toxin specifically targets tissues such as the myocardium, adrenals, and nerve endings.

questions.text: 37. A 27-year-old male patient presents with a history of urethral discharge for the last four days. A gram stain smear of the discharge is shown in the image given below. Which of the following transport media can be used for the causative organism?
questions.solution:
History of urethral discharge, along with the image showing gram-negative diplococci within the polymorphs, is characteristic of Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection. Stuart’s medium is the transport medium used for Neisseria.

Gonorrhea is a sexually transmitted disease caused by N. gonorrhoeae. The major symptoms include urethritis, vaginal discharge, dyspareunia, and dysuria. In the laboratory diagnosis of N. gonorrhea, the discharge on Gram's stain reveals gram‐negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes. 

It acidifies glucose but not maltose in serum sugars. Stuart's medium is used for transport, while Thayer-Martin agar is used as a selective medium to isolate N. gonorrhoeae. Cultures can be obtained from chocolate agar or Mueller-Hinton agar. 

Stuart’s medium is the transport medium used for Neisseria gonorrhea and Neisseria meningitides. It is a semisolid, non-nutrient medium. Charcoal present in the medium neutralizes certain bacterial inhibitors, while a reducing agent prevents oxidation.

Other options:

Option A: Cary-Blair medium is a buffered solution of sodium chloride, sodium thioglycollate, disodium phosphate, and calcium chloride at a pH of 8.4. It is a suitable transport medium for Salmonella, Shigella, and Vibrios.

Option B: Pike's medium (Option B) is a blood agar containing 1 in 1,000,000 crystal violet and 1 in 16,000 sodium azide. It is used as a transport medium for Streptococcus.

Option D: Autoclaved seawater serves as a holding medium for Vibrio cholerae.

Vibrio cholera

Cary Blair medium

questions.text:
38. Which of the following is true with respect to viral antigen processing and presentation in an infected cell?

MHC - Major histocompatibility complex

choices.text: Occurs only in the professional antigen presenting cells
The newly synthesized viral proteins are cleaved within an endosome
The processed viral proteins are mostly associated with class II MHC molecule
The viral antigens are presented to the CD8+ T cells

questions.solution:
The viral antigens are presented to the CD8+ T cells via the cytosolic pathway of antigen processing and presentation.

There are 2 pathways of antigen processing and presentation:

* Cytosolic pathway - The endogenous (intracellular) antigens are cleaved within a proteasome (option B) and the cleaved fragments are associated with the class I MHC protein (option C) in the rough endoplasmic reticulum. The complex of the peptide fragment and class I MHC protein then migrates to the cell surface, where it is presented to the CD8 cytotoxic T cells. This pathway is essential for the clearance of endogenously synthesized antigens like viral proteins and tumor antigens and occurs in most of the nucleated somatic cells of the body (option A).

* Endocytic pathway - The exogenous antigens (extracellular microbes, toxins) are cleaved into peptide fragments within an endosome, where the fragments are associated with the class II MHC proteins. This complex then migrates to the cell surface to be presented to the CD4 helper T cells. This pathway occurs only in antigen-presenting cells such as B cells, macrophages, and dendritic cells.



Pearl PM1552: MHC Classes I and II

MHC Class I

MHC Class II

Expressed on all nucleated cells (except sperms) and platelets

Expressed on antigen-presenting cells: macrophages, B lymphocytes, dendritic cells

Consist of a polymorphic α, heavy-chain, linked non-covalently to β2-microglobulin

Heterodimer consisting of non-covalently associated α and β chains, both of which are polymorphic.

α chains are encoded by three genes- HLA-A, HLA-B, and HLA-C

Encoded by HLA-D, with subregions: HLA-DP, HLA-DQ, and HLA-DR.

Display antigenic peptides that are derived from viral and tumor proteins

Present antigens that are internalized into vesicles, and derived from extracellular microbes 

Class I complexes are recognized by CD8+ T cells

 

Class II complexes are recognized by CD4+ T cells

Endogenous peptide is the type of antigen presented to CD8+ T cells

 Exogenous antigen is the type of antigen presented to CD4+ T cells 

Presents antigen via the cytosolic pathway

 Presents antigen via the endocytic pathway 

Antigen binding site is present between α1/α2 groove

 Antigen binding site is present between α1/β1 groove 

α3 binds to CD8 molecules on cytotoxic T cells

 β2 binds to CD4 on helper T cells

questions.text: 39. A 25-year-old patient presents to the OPD with complaints of thick, yellow urethral discharge and dysuria. The symptoms developed a few days after the patient had unprotected intercourse with a sex worker. He is diagnosed with gonorrhea. The patient's urethral discharge is inoculated in a selective culture medium. Which of the following drugs is not present in this medium?
questions.solution:
The selective medium used for inoculation in cases of gonorrhea is the Modified Thayer Martin medium. Sulfamethoxazole is not present in it. It is a selective medium made up of four antibiotics: vancomycin, nystatin, colistin and trimethoprim. 

Selective media contain an inhibiting substance that is added to a solid medium. This inhibits the growth of commensals and favours the growth of the required bacterium.

Thayer-Martin medium is a selective medium used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhea and Neisseria meningitides. The antimicrobials present in it suppress the growth of other commensal organisms and selectively favour the growth of Neisseria. The Thayer-Martin medium contains antimicrobials like vancomycin 3.0 mg, colistin 7.5 mg, and nystatin 12.5 units per ml of agar, in chocolate agar. The modified Thayer-Martin medium has an additional antibiotic, trimethoprim, to inhibit Proteus. 

* Vancomycin: to inhibit most gram-positive bacteria.

* Colistin (Polymyxin E): to inhibit most gram-negative bacteria. Neisseria is colistin-resistant and thus grows in this medium.

* Nystatin: to inhibit fungi

* Trimethoprim: to inhibit Proteus.
