questions.text: 40. A sample of water is being tested to assess whether it is suitable for drinking. The detection of which organism provides definitive proof of faecal contamination?
questions.solution:
The detection of Escherichia coli provides definitive proof of fecal contamination.

The presence of fecal pollution in a water sample suggests that the source may be contaminated with enteric pathogens. Two tests are done in succession to identify the presence of E.coli which provides definite proof of fecal pollution. They are

* Presumptive coliform count

* Differential coliform count/ Eijkman test

Presumptive coliform count - The basis of the presumptive coliform test is the inoculation of the water to be tested into tubes containing a suitable liquid medium. These are then incubated and examined after the appropriate period of time. The test is called presumptive because the acid and gas formation observed in the tube may occasionally be due to the presence of some other organism and it has to be confirmed. 

Differential coliform count/ Eijkman test - Following the presumptive test, subcultures are made from all the bottles showing acid and gas to fresh tubes of single-strength Mac Conkey medium pre-warmed to 37°C. These tubes are incubated at 44°C and examined after 24 hours. If Escherichia coli is detected, it is definitive proof of fecal contamination.

Interpretation:

* The Durham's tubes with the presence of gas are deemed to contain E.Coli.

* This can be further confirmed by testing for indole production and citrate utilization.

Other options:

Option A- Recent fecal contamination of water is suggested by the presence of enterococcus (fecal streptococci). Fecal streptococci are found in feces in smaller numbers than E.coli. Streptococci are useful for routine control testing after laying new pipelines or repairs in distribution systems and to detect groundwater contamination.

Option C- Clostridium perfringens also occur regularly in feces but in much smaller numbers than E.coli. The spores are capable of surviving in water for a long time, and they usually resist chlorination. The presence of spores of Clostridium perfringens in natural water suggests that fecal contamination has occurred. But in the absence of the coliform group, it suggests that fecal contamination is a long time ago. They can also be used to assess filtration systems.

Option D- Bacteroides species are present in feces but do not play a significant role in testing and sampling for fecal pollution of water.

Pearl PM1611: WHO Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality, 2017

WHO Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality, 2017

I) Physical parameters:

  Guideline values Comments
Turbidity Ideally, no visible turbidity but permissible standard is < 1.0 NTU (nephelometric turbidity units) for household drinking water. 

It describes the cloudiness of water.

  • >4 NTU – cloudiness visible to naked eye.
  • <4 NTU – measured only by instruments. 
Color Ideally, no visible color but permissible standard is <15 TCU (true color units).  >15 TCU is detectable by the naked eye. 

Taste, odor and temperature

 No health based guideline values It may be indicative of contamination and pollution. High water temperature may enhance growth of microorganisms and influence taste, odor and color.


 

II) Chemical parameters:

  Guideline values
Ammonia

No health based guideline value.

Natural levels in surface and ground water is 0.2 mg/l. Anaerobic groundwater may have up to 3 mg/l.
Aluminium up to 0.9 mg/l
Arsenic

up to 0.01 mg/l

Levels in natural water range from 1 to 2 µg/l.
Chloride

250 mg/l, as above this a detectable taste appears.

Maximum permissible level is 600 mg/l. Sodium thiosulphate can be used to dechlorinate drinking water or tap water.
Copper

up to 2 mg/l.

Excess copper in water can have gastrointestinal effects.
Fluoride

up to 1.5 mg/l. Above this, there is risk of dental and skeletal fluorosis.

Artificial fluoridation range is 0.5 to 1.0 mg/l.
Hydrogen sulphide

Taste and odor threshold is between 0.05 and 0.1 mg/litre.

A rotten egg smell of water indicates hydrogen sulphide.
Nitrates 50 mg/l as nitrate ion, to prevent methaemoglobinaemia and thyroid effects
Nitrites 3 mg/l as nitrite ion, to prevent methemoglobinemia in bottle-fed infants and general population.
pH Acceptable pH is in the range of 6.5 – 8.5.
Lead

up to 0.01 mg/l

The concentration of lead must be kept as low as possible. It is the most undesirable metal in drinking water.
Mercury

0.006 mg/l for inorganic mercury

It is nephrotoxic
Polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAH)

Benzo(a)pyrene up to 0.0007 mg/l

They are to be kept in traces as they are carcinogenic/mutagenic
Sodium Above 200 mg/l may give an unacceptable taste.
Total Dissolved Solids (TDS)

Less than 600 mg/l is generally considered palatable.

TDS consists of inorganic salts and small amounts of organic matter dissolved in water. Water is completely unpalatable above 1200mg/l.


 

III) Biological indicators:

* Total coliform bacteria:

* They are the primary bacterial indicators for drinking water.

* Total coliforms are good indicators of water disinfection because they are abundant in the human intestine and are foreign to potable water.

* E. coli is considered the best indicator of fecal contamination of water when resources for supplementary microbiological examination are limited.

* Guidelines state that coliforms must not be detectable in 100ml of sample water. 

* Multiple tubes method:

* This is a test of bacteriological surveillance of drinking water for coliforms and thereby fecal contamination.

* This test is based on the most probable number (MPN) of coliform organisms.

* Acid and gas production from fermentation due to coliforms are observed for in multiple tubes and a presumptive coliform count is arrived at.

* Confirmation of E. coli can be done by testing for indole formation at 44-45 degrees Celsius or by another test called Eijkman test.

* Faecal streptococci: Their presence in water indicates recent contamination with feces and are regarded as specific indicators of human faecal pollution.

* Clostridium perfringens: They are spore-forming organisms that are resistant to many disinfection methods. They are used as an indicator of protozoa in water and also of remote/intermittent fecal contamination. Their spores are also indicators of the effectiveness of filtration processes.

* Viruses like enteric viruses can also be used as indicators of the disinfection process.

* Heterotrophic plate counts measure a wide range of heterotrophic organisms including bacteria and fungi.

* Coliphages and Bacteroides fragilis phages are evidence of fecal contamination of water. 

IV) Radiological aspects:

* The proposed guidelines for gross alpha activity is 0.5 Bq/litre and for gross beta activity, it is 1.0 Bq/litre of drinking water.

questions.text: 41. A microbiologist is studying the various growth phases of a bacterium. The findings are plotted in the image below. In phase 3, which of the following is correct about the total cell count and the viable cell count respectively?
questions.solution:
In the stationary phase (3) of the bacterial growth curve, the total cell count increases while the viable cell count remains constant.

In the stationary phase of the bacterial growth curve, growth ceases completely due to exhaustion of nutrients and accumulation of toxic products. However, cell turnover continues to take place in this phase. The slow loss of cells occurring due to death is balanced by the formation of new cells through division. Thus, the viable count stays constant as viable cells that die are replaced by new cells. The total cell count of viable and dead cells, however, increases as the number of dead cells keeps increasing.

The image given below shows a graph plotting the log of the number of bacteria against time in a population of cells termed batch culture, denoting the bacterial growth curve.



Phases of bacterial growth curve:

Lag phase: It is the initial period of time required for adaptation of the cells to the new environment, during which necessary enzymes and metabolic intermediates are built up in adequate quantities for multiplication. Hence, there is no increase in cell number, but cell size increases, and maximum cell size is obtained towards the end of this phase.

Log phase: Cells start dividing exponentially or by geometric progression with time. Cells are smaller and stain uniformly. One of two things limits this exponential growth:

* Exhaustion of nutrients in the medium required for growth

* Accumulation of toxic metabolites that inhibit growth

Stationary phase: When the exponential growth of cells is limited, the cells enter a stationary phase where cell growth ceases completely. Cell turnover is seen where the rate at which cells die is equally balanced with the rate of formation of new cells through growth and division.

In this phase, a bacterial culture phenomenon is noted where bacterial cells become viable but non-culturable (VBNC). This is thought to be triggered by starvation, where the bacterial cells enter into a dormant state, resulting in no morphological changes. When appropriate conditions are met, VNBC microbes resume growth.

Phase of decline: Cell viability begins to decrease at a defined rate from nutritional exhaustion, toxin accumulation, and the action of autolytic enzymes. The death rate increases until it reaches a steady level, and as a result, the cell population decreases in this phase. Involution forms are common.

questions.text: 42. The most abundant subclass of IgG present in the serum is ______.
questions.solution:
IgG1 is the most abundant subclass of IgG present in serum. It represents about 65% of the total IgG.

IgG antibody has 4 subclasses. It plays a role in immunological reactions such as complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of viruses and toxins. IgG1 has the highest concentration in the serum, while IgG4 has the lowest concentration. 

IgG is the only maternal immunoglobulin that is normally transported across the placenta, especially the IgG1 and IgG3 subclasses. 

IgG2 is directed against polysaccharide antigens and hence is important in the host defense mechanism against encapsulated bacteria.

IgG3 is an effective activator of the complement, whereas IgG4 does not activate complement due to its compact structure.

Pearl PM2056: Properties of immunoglobulin classes

IgG:

* Half-life- 23 days

* Appears late, indicates chronic infection

* It is the only maternal Ig to cross the placenta.

* Has 4 subclasses.

* Facilitates opsonization (via Fc receptor binding)

* Causes complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of toxins and viruses.

IgM:

* Half-life- 5 days

* Has the highest molecular weight and is a pentamer.

* Polysaccharides and lipids mainly stimulate IgM secretion.

* Intravascular distribution.

* Appears early, indicates recent infection.

* Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.

* It causes agglutination, hemolysis, complement fixation and opsonization.

IgD:

* Half-life- 2-8 days.

* Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.

* Serves as recognition receptors for antigens.

IgE:

* Half-life- 1-5 days

* Causes type I hypersensitivity.

* It is the only heat-labile antibody.

* Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

IgA:

* Half-life- 6 days

* It is of 2 types- Serum IgA and Secretory IgA 

* Secretory IgA (A dimer) results in mucosal immunity.

questions.text: 43. A 45-year-old HIV-positive man presents with chronic watery diarrhea. Oocysts identified in stool microscopy raise suspicion of Cystoisospora belli. Which characteristic of the sporulated oocyst confirms the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
2 sporocysts with 4 sporozoites each accurately describes the key diagnostic feature of Cystoisospora oocysts.

The presence of two sporocysts, each containing four sporozoites (a total of eight sporozoites), is highly specific to Cystoisospora and helps differentiate it from other diarrheal parasites.

The oocyst of Cystoisospora undergoes sporulation of oocysts occurs in the soil, which is the infective stage of the parasite. The immature oocysts identified in stool samples are acid-fast, elongated-ovoid, and contain two sporoblasts. They cause profuse diarrhea in immunocompromised patients.

On maturation, the sporoblasts convert into sporocysts. Each sporocyst contains four crescent-shaped sporozoites. 

Comparison of coccidian parasites causing diarrhea in an immunocompromised host :

PROPERTY CRYPTOSPORIDIUM CYCLOSPORA CYSTOISOSPORA

Sporulated oocyst

4-6 μm, round,  contains four sporozoites

8-12 μm, round, contains 2 sporocyst each having two sporozoites

23-36 μm, oval, contain two sporocysts, each having four sporozoites.
Acid-fast detection  Uniformly acid-fast Variable acid-fast Uniformly acid-fast
Sporulation of the oocyst Occurs inside the host cell Occurs in soil Occurs in soil
Diagnostic form Sporulated cyst Unsporulated cyst Unsporulated oocyst

questions.text:
44. Match the following egg characteristics with the corresponding organism

* An egg that floats in a saturated salt solution and is bile-stained

* An egg that does not float in a saturated salt solution and is bile-stained

* An egg that floats in a saturated salt solution and is non-bile-stained

* An egg that does not float in when unfertilized, and floats when fertilized

* Ancylostoma duodenale

* Ascaris lumbricoides

* Trichuris trichiura

* Taenia solium
questions.solution:
* An egg that floats in saturated salt solution and is bile stained -Trichuris trichiura

* An egg that does not float in saturated salt solution and is bile stained - Taenia solium (pork tapeworm)

* An egg that floats in saturated salt solution and is non-bile stained - Ancylostoma duodenale

* An egg that does not float in when unfertilized, and floats when fertilized - Ascaris lumbricoides

Helminths whose eggs do not float in the saturated solution

* Unfertilized eggs of Ascaris lumbricoides

* Eggs of Taenia solium and Taenia saginata

* Eggs of all intestinal flukes

questions.text: 45. A 28-year-old man presents with chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and malabsorption. An endoscopy was done, and the organism, as shown in the given image, was seen on the intestinal surface. Which of the following statements is true about the definitive and intermediate host of the organism?

choices.text: Snail is the definitive host, and man is the intermediate host
Man is the definitive host, and snail is the intermediate host
Pig is the definitive host, and fish is the intermediate host
Fish is the definitive host, and pig is the intermediate host

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of Fasciolopsis buski infection, and the correct statement about it is that man is the definitive host, and snail is the intermediate host.

Fasciolopsiasis is an infection caused by Fasciolopsis buski, commonly known as the giant intestinal fluke. This parasite is the largest and most prevalent intestinal fluke known to infect humans.

The life cycle of F. buski mirrors that of other trematodes, except for Schistosoma.

Hosts: F. buski has a definitive host (pigs or humans) and two intermediate hosts:snails (first) and aquatic plants (second). Transmission is by consuming contaminated aquatic plants that harbor the infective metacercaria larvae.

The life cycle of F. buski is shown below:



Clinical Manifestations:

* Light infection: May be asymptomatic. Attachment to the intestinal mucosa can lead to local inflammation and ulcerations, resulting in mucus and blood in the stool.

* Severe infection: Can cause partial obstruction of the intestinal tract.

* Malabsorption and protein-losing enteropathy: May occur, characterized by profuse yellowish-green stools.

* Laboratory findings: Marked eosinophilia and leukocytosis are commonly observed.

F. buski is diagnosed by detecting numerous operculated eggs in stool samples. These eggs are large (130–140 μm by 80–85 μm), yellowish-brown, and operculated, similar to Fasciola hepatica eggs. 

Stool concentration methods like formol-ether sedimentation enhance egg detection. Definitive diagnosis involves identifying the adult worm. While immunological and molecular methods exist, microscopic identification of eggs remains the primary diagnostic tool.

Endoscopic image of the organism is shown below:



Treatment: Praziquantel, administered as 25 mg/kg in three daily doses, is the preferred drug. Niclosamide can be used as an alternative.

Note: F. buski and Fasciola hepatica are both flukes, but Fasciolopsis buski is an intestinal fluke without a cephalic cone and has unbranched testes, while Fasciola hepatica is a liver fluke with a cephalic cone and branched testes. F. buski causes intestinal obstruction, whereas F. hepatica causes hepatic and biliary inflammation.

questions.text:
46. A sheep farmer presents with abdominal pain, jaundice and diarrhoea associated with eosinophilia. Bile stained and operculated eggs are seen on stool examination. Match the following points about the causative parasite:

1. Habitat A. Aquatic vegetation
2. First intermediate host B. Sheep
3. Second intermediate host C. Biliary tract
4. Definitive host D. Snail
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of fascioliasis, an infection with the sheep liver fluke, Fasciola hepatica.

The correct options are:

1. Habitat C. Biliary tract of man
2. First intermediate host D. Snail
3. Second intermediate host A. Aquatic vegetation
4. Definitive host B. Sheep


Fasciola hepatica is a liver fluke (trematode) that resides in the liver and the lumen of the biliary passages and causes fascioliasis. It mainly affects sheep and other domestic animals. Infection in sheep and man is acquired by ingestion of metacercariae encysted on aquatic vegetation.

* Definitive host: Sheep, goat, cattle, and man.

* Intermediate host: Snails of the genus Lymnaea and Succinea.

* Encystment occurs on aquatic plants, which act as the second intermediate host.

The clinical features include fever, tender hepatomegaly, right upper quadrant pain, obstructive jaundice and eosinophilia. Diagnosis is made by the detection of eggs in stool and aspirated bile.

Oral triclabendazole (10 mg/kg once) is the treatment of choice.

The life cycle of Fasciola hepatica is shown in the image below:

questions.text: 47. A patient with end-stage liver disease is being counseled about transplant and the need for HLA typing. Identify the incorrect statement regarding the HLA genes.

choices.text: MHC Class I proteins are encoded by HLA-A,B,C
MHC Class II proteins are encoded by HLA-D
The MHC loci are present on chromosome 6
Either the maternal or paternal HLA genes will dominate

questions.solution:
Option D is incorrect.

HLA genes are codominant, which means that the MHC proteins encoded by the genes from both the maternal and paternal chromosomes are expressed.

The Human Leukocyte Antigen (HLA) genes encode for proteins that allow the immune system to recognise and differentiate self and non-self proteins, thus playing a major role in the identification of foreign tissue, such as in the context of transplants. Every individual has HLA genes, which are clustered into the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) located on chromosome 6, and are inherited from each parent.

Tissues with identical MHC complexes, such as from the same individual (autografts) or tissues from individuals with identical HLA genes, such as in identical twins (isografts), are not recognised as foreign and hence not rejected, whereas mismatched MHC is the basis for tissue rejection

The HLA A, B, and C genes encode proteins that form MHC Class I proteins, and the HLA-D genes (DP, DQ, and DR) encode proteins that form MHC Class II proteins.

Pearl PM1552: MHC Classes I and II

MHC Class I

MHC Class II

Expressed on all nucleated cells (except sperms) and platelets

Expressed on antigen-presenting cells: macrophages, B lymphocytes, dendritic cells

Consist of a polymorphic α, heavy-chain, linked non-covalently to β2-microglobulin

Heterodimer consisting of non-covalently associated α and β chains, both of which are polymorphic.

α chains are encoded by three genes- HLA-A, HLA-B, and HLA-C

Encoded by HLA-D, with subregions: HLA-DP, HLA-DQ, and HLA-DR.

Display antigenic peptides that are derived from viral and tumor proteins

Present antigens that are internalized into vesicles, and derived from extracellular microbes 

Class I complexes are recognized by CD8+ T cells

 

Class II complexes are recognized by CD4+ T cells

Endogenous peptide is the type of antigen presented to CD8+ T cells

 Exogenous antigen is the type of antigen presented to CD4+ T cells 

Presents antigen via the cytosolic pathway

 Presents antigen via the endocytic pathway 

Antigen binding site is present between α1/α2 groove

 Antigen binding site is present between α1/β1 groove 

α3 binds to CD8 molecules on cytotoxic T cells

 β2 binds to CD4 on helper T cells


Pearl PM2114: Types of transplants

Type  Definition
Orthotopic

Organ implanted in the same anatomic location in the recipient as it was in the donor. Diseased organ is removed. Eg: heart, lung, liver, intestine
Heterotopic

Organ implanted in a different anatomic location. Diseased organ is left in place. Eg: Kidney, pancreas
Auxiliary transplantation Partial tissue from the donor is used which acts as temporary support for the recipient's injured organ, which remains in place. Eg: left lobe of liver
Autotransplant  Transfer of cells/tissues/organs within the same person. 
Allotransplant Transfer of cells/tissues/organs within the same species. 
Xenotransplant Transfer of cells/tissues/organs in a different species.
Isograft Transfer of organ or tissue within genetically identical individuals. Eg: Identical twins

questions.text: 48. Identify the part that differentiates a dark-field microscope from a light microscope.
questions.solution:
The condenser lens, which is marked C, differentiates a dark-field microscope from a light microscope.

Dark-field microscopy improves the contrast by using a special condenser called a dark-field condenser. Compared to a light microscope, a reflected light is used instead of transmitted light, without letting any ray of light fall directly on the objective lens.

The dark field condenser has a central circular stop that illuminates the object with a cone of light. Light rays falling on the object are reflected or scattered onto the objective lens, making the object appear self-luminous against a dark background. The contrast gives an illusion of increased resolution.

Very slender organisms, such as spirochetes, which are not visible under ordinary illumination, can be clearly seen under the dark field microscope.

Other Options: A- Ocular lens, B- Objective lens, and D- Light source.

The image given below shows a light microscope and its parts.

questions.text: 49. A 22-year-old boy develops an intensely pruritic maculopapular rash on both of his legs 2 days after swimming in a freshwater pond. The image of the rash is shown below. Which of the following organisms is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this rash?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the most likely involved organism is Schistosoma mansoni.

The clinical scenario of a man developing intensely pruritic maculopapular rash on both of his legs 2 days after swimming in a freshwater pond is suggestive of cercarial dermatitis (swimmer’s itch), which is caused by Schistosoma mansoni. It manifests 2-3 days after larval penetration and is self-limiting.

Adult worms of S. mansoni live in the inferior mesenteric vein, and their infective form is a fork-tailed cercaria.

After 4- 8 weeks of the cercarial invasion, high worm load, and egg antigen stimuli lead to the formation of immune complexes, which result in a serum sickness-like illness termed Katayama fever. They present with high-grade fever, rash, arthralgia, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, and eosinophilia. 

When eggs get deposited in the small intestine, patients develop abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea for a long time, called intestinal bilharziasis. The eggs deposited in the intestinal wall lead to microabscesses, granulomas, hyperplasia, and fibrosis. 

The drug of choice is praziquantel 40mg/kg single oral dose. Oxamniquine 15mg/kg single oral dose is also an effective dose.

Other Options

Option B: Ancylostoma duodenale causes cutaneous larva migrans, which are serpiginous tracks commonly found on the feet after contact with sandy soil. An image of cutaneous larva migrans is shown below:



Option C: Ascaris lumbricoides more commonly causes intestinal infection. They can cause urticaria and dermatitis.

Option D: Strongyloides stercoralis causes chronic diarrhea, urticaria, and creeping eruption. It can cause larva currens, which is a serpiginous urticarial rash as shown below.

questions.text: 50. Which method of antibiotic sensitivity tests is shown in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The method of antibiotic sensitivity test shown in the given image is the Stokes method.

Stokes Method: It assesses bacterial sensitivity or resistance by comparing the zones of inhibition between standard and test bacteria.

Bacteria are classified as:

* Susceptible: The bacterium is inhibited by the drug concentration typically achieved in the blood at recommended dosages.

* Intermediately Susceptible: The bacterium is susceptible to the drug at higher than normal dosages, or the drug is clinically effective at body sites where it is physiologically concentrated.

* Resistant: The bacterium is not inhibited by the drug, and specific resistance mechanisms are present in the bacterial isolate.

Laboratory testing for antibiotic sensitivity can be done by:

* Diffusion method- Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion method, Stokes disc diffusion method

* Dilution method- broth dilution method, agar dilution method

* Combination of diffusion and dilution method- E–test (Epsilometer)

* Automated methods- VITEK-2, Phoenix systems

Other Options

Option A: Kirby–Bauer: Uses standardized inoculum and disks, results interpreted from zone sizes compared with tables, without a side-by-side reference. Image of Kirby–Bauer disk diffusion is shown below:



Option B: E-test- Uses a strip with an antibiotic gradient to read the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC). The image of the E-test is shown below:



Option D: Microbroth dilution- Determines MIC in liquid media. An image of the microbroth dilution technique is shown below:
